This IRM supersedes IRM 6.410.9 dated November 27, 2018, Training Evaluation Policy.
All Servicewide Learning & Education employees or personnel, including program managers, education specialists and others involved in training activities within each business unit.
Robin D. Bailey Jr., IRS Human Capital Officer

Level 4 Training Evaluation Policies and Procedures
) This IRM provides general policy and guidance needed to conduct Levels
training evaluations at the IRS. (
) Purpose : This transmittal revises IRM
, Training Evaluation Policy for Servicewide Learning & Education (SL&E). (
) Audience : All Business Units. (
) Policy Owner : The Human Capital Office (HCO), Enterprise Talent Planning and Development (ETPD) Division . (
) Program Owner : The HCO-ETPD Servicewide Training and Event Manage- ment (STEM) office is responsible for the administration, policy development and updates related to this IRM. (
) Primary Stakeholders : All SL&E organizations. (

) Program Goals : This IRM supports the ETPD goal of supporting a culture of continuous self-development and mission-focused learning for employees by providing tools for measuring and reporting the overall effectiveness of training programs at the IRS. (

) The IRS, through the joint efforts of its learning and education community, develops and delivers a variety of training courses that are designed to contrib- ute to mission accomplishment and meet organizational goals. Effectively evaluating these training courses helps us determine course improvement op- portunities and the overall value that training is adding to business results the organization’s mission. (

) The IRS follows established procedures outlined in the instructional design model known as the Training Development Quality Assurance System (TDQAS) to administer training evaluations. Speciﬁc procedures address the evaluation of learner reaction, and achievement and the evaluation of job per- formance and organizational impact. Adherence to TDQAS processes ensures procedural consistency in the overall quality of our training systems and products. IRM
, Learning and Education Policy, and its subsections dress the actions associated with the evaluations phase of TDQAS. (
) Per Title
of the Code of Federal Regulations (
CFR
), agencies must evaluate their training programs annually to determine how well such plans and programs contribute to mission accomplishment and meet organiza- tional performance goals. (
) IRM

uses the following terms and lists speciﬁc training deﬁnitions in most subsections of this IRM: a. Consolidated Report - A report maintained in the course ﬁle that includes data analysis, a summary, and recommendations for improve- ment based on Level
, and

training evaluation results. b. Evaluation Management System (EMS) - The official system of record for managing training evaluation data. Certain evaluation data captured the Learning Management System (LMS) is systemically transferred to EMS to streamline data collection and provide a more strategic approach in analyzing and interpreting evaluation data. Consolidated Report - A report maintained in the course ﬁle that includes data analysis, a summary, and recommendations for improve- ment based on Level
, and

training evaluation results. Evaluation Management System (EMS) - The official system of record for managing training evaluation data. Certain evaluation data captured in the Learning Management System (LMS) is systemically transferred to EMS to streamline data collection and provide a more strategic approach in analyzing and interpreting evaluation data.
Item

Any event tracked in the LMS for learning history completions, and/or for tracking usage. Items include but are not limited to: Continuing Professional Education (CPE), courses, and workshops. Learning and Education (L&E)
Organization within a business unit, or designated area within HCO, that develops courseware and provides training and education support. Learning Management System (LMS)

The official system of record for training. It offers development and delivery of course evaluations. Access LMS and resources at https://irssource.web.irs.gov/Pages/ITM.aspx . Mission Critical Training
Any training that is required to meet em
ployee and organizational performance goals, or training that, if not con

tinued, would result in signiﬁcant loss to the agency measured in terms of lost taxes, customer conﬁdence, or employee productivity. Examples of mission critical training include, but are not limited to:

mission critical training include, but are not limited to: • Courses developed in the prior (FY) and designated for the ﬁrst quarter as mission critical, • Recruit and basic training for mission critical and non-mission critical positions, • Functional and cross-functional leadership training, • Classroom instructor training, on-the-job (OJI) instruction, instructor training workshops, • Discretionary Out-Service – unanticipated mission critical needs that need out service funds. g. New World Kirkpatrick Model - A four-level blended approach to train- ing evaluation that focuses on transferring learning to behavior and align- ing training with organizational goals. h. Priority

- Mission critical training that must be timely delivered or de- veloped during the FY. This training is necessary for the employee to function in their basic position such as ﬁling season readiness, new hire, and tax law. i. Priority

- Mission critical training that must be delivered or developed during the FY. The employee can still function in their basic position but needs this training to perform at a higher job level such as higher phase training, specialty training, and CPE. j. Priority

- Training that should be delivered or developed during the FY but may be postponed until the latter part of the FY or the following FY without signiﬁcantly impacting operations. This training enhances existing employee by enabling employees to operate more effectively. k. Priority

- Training that could be postponed to the following FY with no negative impact if there are insufficient training funds or resource limitations. This is training that enhances performance but is not necessary to perform daily activities. l. Rubric - A set of criteria for grading assignments. Rubrics usually have evaluative criteria, quality deﬁnitions for those criteria at particular levels achievement, and a scoring strategy. m. Training - The process of providing employees the programs, courses, other instruction they need to develop new skills to perform a task or pro- cess and/or enhance or improve current skills in their individual job performance. Effective training may result in observably changed behavior. n. Training Development Quality Assurance System (TDQAS) - The in- structional design model used by the IRS that guides the processes of

training assessment, analysis, design, development, implementation, evaluation. The TDQAS development model ensures high-quality training products and services. For more information see IRM
, Learning and Education Policy , and its subsections. o. Training Event - Instruction that is conducted in a structured learning vironment (
earning and/or non-
earning) and contains behavioral jectives linked to or derived from job competencies or tasks. (

) The Servicewide Training Evaluation Program (STEP) is responsible for: a. Establishing training evaluation policies and procedures for the IRS. b. Providing training and resources for L&E professionals such as: • Levels of Evaluation Training, • Training Evaluation & Measurement for Performance Optimization (TEMPO) Training, and • Webinars. c. Administrating the EMS, which includes: • Issuing appropriate accesses, • Contract and billing, and • Troubleshooting. d. Providing technical support and consultation for training evaluation opment. e. Reporting Servicewide training evaluation results. f. Communicating evaluation information. g. Creating standardized Level
evaluations designed consistently captures, compiles, quantiﬁes and reports data. h. Maintaining the STEP Shar
oint site and the *HCO Servicewide tion Program mailbox . (

through

evaluation requirements for training courses, in conjunction with business unit customers. b. Creating and maintaining items in the LMS, to include: • Updating evaluation requirements ﬁelds and • Associating the right standardized Level
training evaluation surveys items. Policy

Note: If a training event includes multiple courses, apply the policies and proce- dures contained in this IRM individually to each course within the training event. (

training evaluations. b. Batching the results of paper Level
training evaluations and forwarding to the EMS vendor for processing. c. Entering data from Form
, Level
Instructor Data Capture , into LMS. d. Informing instructors of Level
training evaluation requirements. (
) Evaluation is the phase of the TDQAS in which data is systematically collected, analyzed, and interpreted to determine the effectiveness of training. (

) The IRS uses a four-level approach to training evaluation, based on one of leading industry standards in the ﬁeld of training. This systematic approach, known as the Kirkpatrick Model, with New World Kirkpatrick Model enhance- ments, ensures that the IRS gathers complete data that measures the effectiveness of training, while enabling course owners to identify course im- provement opportunities. The Kirkpatrick Model effectively demonstrates the strategic value that training programs add to business results and the organi- zation’s mission. (
) The four levels of training evaluation in the New World Kirkpatrick Model are: a. Level
: Reaction - The degree to which participants ﬁnd the training favorable, engaging and relevant to their jobs.

) Evaluation is the phase of the TDQAS in which data is systematically collected, analyzed, and interpreted to determine the effectiveness of training. (

) The IRS uses a four-level approach to training evaluation, based on one of the leading industry standards in the ﬁeld of training. This systematic approach, known as the Kirkpatrick Model, with New World Kirkpatrick Model enhance- ments, ensures that the IRS gathers complete data that measures the effectiveness of training, while enabling course owners to identify course im- provement opportunities. The Kirkpatrick Model effectively demonstrates the strategic value that training programs add to business results and the organi- zation’s mission. (
) The four levels of training evaluation in the New World Kirkpatrick Model are: a. Level
: Reaction - The degree to which participants ﬁnd the training favorable, engaging and relevant to their jobs.
Note: If a training event includes multiple courses, apply the policies and proce- dures contained in this IRM individually to each course within the training
Evaluation is the phase of the TDQAS in which data is systematically collected, analyzed, and interpreted to determine the effectiveness of training.
Level 1: Reaction - The degree to which participants ﬁnd the training favorable, engaging and relevant to their jobs.
b. Level
: Learning - The degree to which participants acquire the intended knowledge, skills, attitude, conﬁdence and commitment based on their participation in the training. c. Level
: Behavior - The degree to which participants apply what they learned during training when they are back on the job. d. Level

: Results - The degree to which targeted outcomes occur as a result of training. Targeted outcomes are training programs’ highest-level goals. These should tie into the organization’s overall purpose and business need. (
) Level
training evaluation is the degree to which participants ﬁnd training favorable, engaging and relevant to their jobs. Its purpose is to assess the immediate reaction of learners to the training. (
) New World Kirkpatrick Model Level

dimensions include: a. Customer Satisfaction - participants’ satisfaction with the training. b. Engagement - the degree to which participants are actively involved in contributing to the learning experience. c. Relevance - the degree to which participants believe they will have the opportunity to use or apply what they learned in training on the job. (
) The Level
evaluation process enables business units to gather and interpret participants’ reactions to the training they received. (
) Level
training evaluation is the degree to which participants acquire the intended knowledge, skills, attitude, conﬁdence and commitment based on their participation in training. Level
training evaluation can be either knowledge-based or performance-based. (
) New World Kirkpatrick Model Level

training evaluation dimensions include: a. Knowledge - “I know it.” b. Skill - “I can do it right now.” c. Attitude - “I believe this will be worthwhile to do on the job.” d. Conﬁdence - “I think I can do it on the job.” e. Commitment - “I intend to do it on the job.” (
) The Level
training evaluation process enables business units to gather and interpret participants’ level of learning based on the training they received. (
) Level
training evaluation can be quantitative or qualitative in nature. a. Quantitative tests or assessments are those that express results in numbers. Examples of quantitative Level

evaluations include, but are not limited to: • Traditional knowledge tests (multiple choice, ﬁll in the blank, calculate the equation, complete the form, etc.) • Knowledge checks, and • Individual case studies (with rubric provided for scoring). b. Qualitative methods don’t yield numerical results or are not easily scored. They are any means by which students receive input and guiding Policy
page
Level
: Learning - The degree to which participants acquire the intended knowledge, skills, attitude, conﬁdence and commitment based on their participation in the training. Level
: Behavior - The degree to which participants apply what they learned during training when they are back on the job. Level

: Results - The degree to which targeted outcomes occur as a result of training. Targeted outcomes are training programs’ highest-level goals. These should tie into the organization’s overall purpose and business need.
(2) New World Kirkpatrick Model Level 2 training evaluation dimensions include:
The Level 2 training evaluation process enables business units to gather and interpret participants’ level of learning based on the training they received.
Qualitative methods don’t yield numerical results or are not easily scored. They are any means by which students receive input and guiding
feedback on their relative performance to help them improve. Examples of qualitative Level 2 evaluations include, but are not limited to:
Group/team exercises,
Simulations,
Presentations,
Observations,
Work reviews,
Self
assessments,
Pass/fail assessments,
Pre/post assessments,
Questionnaires,
Role plays,
Interviews, and
Action learning.
Note: Developing a grading rubric to calculate grades and scores can convert most qualitative methods to quantitative methods.
) Level
training evaluation is the degree to which participants apply what they learned during training when they are back on the job. (
) New World Kirkpatrick Model Level

training evaluation dimensions include: a. Required Drivers - processes and systems that reinforce, monitor, encourage and reward performance. Examples of required drivers include work review checklists, job aids, recognition, coaching, mentoring, etc. b. Critical Behaviors - the few, speciﬁc actions that will have the biggest impact on the desired results if performed consistently on the job. For IRS, critical behaviors are the same as enabling learning objectives (ELOs) and/or terminal learning objectives (TLOs). c. On-the-Job Learning - a culture and expectation that individuals are re- sponsible for maintaining the knowledge and skills to enhance their own performance. (
) The Level
training evaluation process enables business units to gather and interpret the level of impact the training had on participants behavior. (
) Level

training evaluation is the degree to which targeted outcomes occur as a result of training. It assesses the impact of the improvements in the trainees’ performance on the mission of the organization. Business units must be able to identify and provide data on measures that have organizational impact. (
) New World Kirkpatrick Model Level

training evaluation dimensions include leading indicators which are short-term observations and measurements sug- gesting that critical behaviors are on track to create a positive impact on desired results. Examples of leading indicators include balanced measure ratings, compliance ratings, customer response ratings, etc. (
) The Level
evaluation process enables business units to gather and interpret the results that the training had on the organization.
Level 3 training evaluation is the degree to which participants apply what they learned during training when they are back on the job.
New World Kirkpatrick Model Level 3 training evaluation dimensions include:
a. Required Drivers

processes and systems that reinforce, monitor, encourage and reward performance. Examples of required drivers include work review checklists, job aids, recognition, coaching, mentoring, etc. b. Critical Behaviors

the few, speciﬁc actions that will have the biggest impact on the desired results if performed consistently on the job. For the IRS, critical behaviors are the same as enabling learning objectives (ELOs) and/or terminal learning objectives (TLOs). c. On
the
Job Learning
a culture and expectation that individuals are re
sponsible for maintaining the knowledge and skills to enhance their own performance.
The Level 3 training evaluation process enables business units to gather and interpret the level of impact the training had on participants behavior.
The Level 4 evaluation process enables business units to gather and interpret the results that the training had on the organization.
Policies and (
) All training events require Level
training evaluations: a. The L&E office must document the Level
evaluation requirements for each item in the LMS. The “Level
Evaluation” ﬁeld must be populated with “Level
is required (Required).” b. The L&E office must associate the right standardized online Level
training evaluation to each item in the LMS. The four standardized online Level
training evaluation forms currently available are: • L
-CLS-
(Classroom Course Evaluation) - used to evaluate instructor led, classroom training events. • L
-BLD-
(Blended - Classroom, Computer and Self-Directed Evalua- tion) - used to evaluate instructor-led training events with classroom technology-based components. • L
-VIR-
(Virtual Evaluation) - used to evaluate virtual training events. • L
-SD-

(Self-Directed Training Evaluation) - used to evaluate self- directed training events. c. Feedback from participants, instructors, the L&E community and the National Treasury Employees Union (NTEU) was considered when oping the standardized Level
training evaluation surveys. d. By agreement, NTEU will be provided information upon request. (
) Participants completing Level
training evaluations is voluntary but strongly encouraged. (
) Level
training evaluations must be completed during normal duty hours. (
) Level
training evaluations must be anonymous and conﬁdential (i.e., no names, SEIDs, and/or other self-identifying data will be used). Level
Evaluations (
) Level
training evaluations are systemically issued through the LMS when course with an associated standardized online Level
training evaluation is recorded in the employee’s learning history. The LMS systemically captures responses. (
) Standardized paper Level
training evaluations are available for employees with restricted access to computers or as a reasonable accommodation. a. The two standardized paper Level
training evaluation forms currently available are: • L
-CLS-
(Classroom Course Evaluation) - used to evaluate instructor led, classroom training events. • L
-VIR-
(Virtual Evaluation) - used to evaluate virtual training events. b. The VLM or CLS office must manually administer the standardized paper Level
evaluations. c. The VLMor CLS office must send the results to the EMS vendor for into the EMS.
All training events require Level 1 training evaluations:
The L&E office must document the Level
evaluation requirements for each item in the LMS. The “Level
Evaluation” ﬁeld must be populated with “Level
is required (Required).” The L&E office must associate the right standardized online Level
training evaluation to each item in the LMS. The four standardized online Level
training evaluation forms currently available are:
L
-CLS-
(Classroom Course Evaluation) - used to evaluate instructor led, classroom training events. L
-BLD-
(Blended - Classroom, Computer and Self-Directed Evalua- tion) - used to evaluate instructor-led training events with classroom and technology-based components. L
-VIR-
(Virtual Evaluation) - used to evaluate virtual training events. L
-SD-
(Self-Directed Training Evaluation) - used to evaluate self- directed training events.
6.410.9.5.1(08-16-2021) Administering Level 1 Training Evaluations
Standardized paper Level 1 training evaluations are available for employees with restricted access to computers or as a reasonable accommodation.
L
-CLS-
(Classroom Course Evaluation) - used to evaluate instructor led, classroom training events. L
-VIR-
(Virtual Evaluation) - used to evaluate virtual training events.
The VLM or CLS office must manually administer the standardized paper Level
evaluations. The VLMor CLS office must send the results to the EMS vendor for input into the EMS.

Evaluation (
) On an annual basis, each L&E organization, through discussion with their business unit customer(s), will determine the priority of training events included on their training plans. (
) The L&E organization must obtain Level
training evaluation results from LMS and/or the EMS. (
) The L&E organization must analyze the Level
training evaluation results all Priority
and Priority
training events within their purview. Analyze Level training evaluation results for Priority
and Priority
training events as resources allow. (
) Analysis of Level
training evaluation results must be compiled and docu- mented in a consolidated report and maintained in the course ﬁle. (
) Documenting Level
training evaluation results analysis must include: a. Recommendations for course improvements and/or corrective actions, b. Annotation if there are no recommendations for improvement. (
) Additional documentation may include, but is not limited to: a. Analysis and assessment of Level
reports with feedback. b. Overall training satisfaction scores. c. Evaluative information from instructors to ensure high-quality, effective and efficient delivery of training. (

) Based on a business unit’s program priorities, one-time training events may excluded from analysis: a. Update the associated item(s) in the LMS to “inactive” once the course information is obsolete. b. Annotate the consolidated report as a one-time event. Training Policies and (
) On an annual basis, each L&E organization, through discussion with their business unit customer(s), will determine which training courses require Level
training evaluations. a. Level
training evaluations should focus on mission-critical training programs and Priority
and

training events but may be required for any training program as determined above. b. To obtain a statistically signiﬁcant sample for measuring the Servicewide training program, at a minimum L&E must require Level
training tions on
% of courses delivered for each business unit. Note: For planning purposes, the
% will be based on the number of courses delivered in the prior FY. c. Consider training and program priorities, training course costs, and available resources when determining Level
training evaluation require- ments. (
) The L&E organization must document the Level
training evaluation require- ments for all training events on the annual business units’ training plan and/or ad hoc requests submitted to STETS.
Analysis of Level 1 training evaluation results must be compiled and docu- mented in a consolidated report and maintained in the course ﬁle.
Recommendations for course improvements and/or corrective actions, or Annotation if there are no recommendations for improvement.
a. When items are created in the LMS, populate the “Level
Evaluation” ﬁeld with “Level
is not required (Optional)” or “Level
is required (Required),” as appropriate. b. If the Level

Evaluation” ﬁeld in LMS prior to the start of any associated training events. (
) Learners must complete Level
training evaluations during normal duty (
) Level
training evaluation results used for reporting and analytical purposes must be anonymous and conﬁdential (i.e., no names, SEIDs, and/or other identifying data will be recorded). (
) Level
training evaluation results for an individual may be included in a opmental guide, or similar document, for employee development purposes to provide individualized coaching. (
) An individual’s Level

training evaluation results are not required to be anonymous when being used for employee development purposes or to provide individualized coaching but can only be shared with a training coordi- nator or the employee’s ﬁrst level manager. (
) No adverse actions will be taken against learners based on Level
training evaluation results. (
) Information gathered through Level
evaluation will not be used to evaluate participants on their annual performance appraisals. (
) Since Level
training evaluations measure the knowledge obtained from subject matter of each individual course, there are no standardized forms questions that are required to be used in all Level
training evaluations. (
) If a course has a Level
training evaluation requirement, L&E must develop Level
evaluation and include in the course. See IRM
) for of Level
evaluations. (
) The L&E organization must develop a rubric (i.e., grading scheme) and methods or procedures for capturing results and include in the course. (
) If using Level
training evaluation results for employee development or coaching purposes, methods and/or procedures for capturing the employee’s individual Level
training evaluation results must be developed and included in the course.
) If a training event has a Level
training evaluation requirement, the evaluation must be administered. Typically, Level
training evaluations are administered during class, however, there are instances when they might be administered after class. (

) The instructor is responsible for scoring and/or compiling the results of Level training evaluations. Note: If an instructor doesn’t have administrator access to the Integrated Talent Management (ITM) , they must contact VLM or CLS for help in gathering electronic Level
evaluation results.
When items are created in the LMS, populate the “Level
Evaluation” ﬁeld with “Level
is not required (Optional)” or “Level
is required (Required),” as appropriate. If the Level
training evaluation requirement for an item changes after it is initially created in the LMS, update the “Level
Evaluation” ﬁeld in the LMS prior to the start of any associated training events.
Learners must complete Level 2 training evaluations during normal duty hours.
The L&E organization must develop a rubric (i.e., grading scheme) and methods or procedures for capturing results and include in the course.
Note: If an instructor doesn’t have administrator access to the Integrated Talent Management (ITM) , they must contact VLM or CLS for help in gathering electronic Level 2 evaluation results.
) Certain Level

evaluation data must be captured in the LMS for Servicewide analysis and reporting purposes. For instructor led and/or blended training, course instructor or business unit designee must: a. Administer and score the Level
evaluation. b. Complete Form
, Level
Instructor Data Capture (IDC) . c. Submit the form to VLM or CLS for input into the LMS. (
) Data captured on the IDC Form includes (as applicable): a. Whether or not a Level

evaluation was administered, including type delivery, (e.g., online (AOL), oral (O), qualitative (QL), quantitative (QN)), b. Reason if not administered, c. Average pre-test score, d. Average post-test score, e. Percentage of improvement, f. Average ﬁnal test score, g. Current trainee count, h. Number of trainees completing, and i. Percentage of trainees completing. (
) To capture comprehensive Level
training evaluation results for more extensive analysis, L&E must communicate any additional reporting require- ments to instructors. (
) If a Level
evaluation is required but not developed and/or administered, the instructor or business unit designee must complete the IDC Form, include reason the Level

was not administered and submit the form to VLM or CLS for input into the LMS. Note: For CPE courses where accreditation (continuing education units or credits) is sought, the courses must adhere to test requirements and standards of the accrediting authority (i.e., American Institute of Certiﬁed Public Accoun- tants or National Association of State Board of Accountancy). Criminal Investigation (CI) training courses must adhere to the standards forth by the Federal Law Enforcement Training Accreditation Board. (

) No adverse actions will be taken against participants or managers based on results of Level
data reports. (
) Information gathered through Level

) If a training event has a Level
training evaluation requirement, Level
training evaluations must be developed. This should be completed during the design and development phase of TDQAS, but may be completed later, if necessary. (
) Level

training evaluations must be developed in the EMS. Note: Paper evaluations may be developed for employees with restricted access computers or as a reasonable accommodation, but the results must be recorded in the EMS. (
) Corresponding participant and manager Level
training evaluations must be developed simultaneously. (
) All Level
training evaluations must include the mandatory training transfer questions to provide results for Servicewide reporting. (
) Level
evaluation instruments must be reviewed and approved by the STEP team prior to delivery. Note: Consult the STEP team for guidance when program managers want to use alternative Level
training evaluations such as focus group interviews. Level
Evaluations (
) Level
training evaluations must be conducted on all training events with a Level
training evaluation requirement. (
) Administer Level

training evaluation after completion of the training event and after employees have been given an opportunity to apply course content while back on the job. They are typically delivered one to six months after training but must be administered within nine months of the end of the training event. (
) If a required Level
training evaluation has not been administered within the typical delivery timeframe, L&E must document the course ﬁle with a scheduled administration date. (
) Once a Level
training evaluation pair is reviewed and approved in the EMS, survey links will be sent to L&E to forward to participants and their managers. Electronic Level
training evaluation responses are systemically captured. (
) If a paper Level
training evaluation is used, a PDF version will be created and sent to L&E. The L&E office is responsible for: a. Administering the Level
paper evaluation. b. Compiling paper Level
training evaluation responses using the batch sheet; and c. Submitting the paper responses and batch sheet to the EMS vendor processing.

) The L&E organization will confer with their assigned business unit executives or designee(s) during the TDQAS assessment phase to determine: a. Program expectations including the customer’s desired results of the training, b. If training warrants a Level

training evaluation and/or it is feasible, c. Whether resources and funding are available and will be committed, d. The extent to which the training impact can be isolated against other factors, and if customer-valued data on business results is available. (
